title: PSI/PORT Score: Pneumonia Severity Index for CAP
description: Estimates mortality for adult patients with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and guides hospitalization decisions. This extensively validated clinical prediction rule uses demographics, comorbidities, physical examination findings, and laboratory results to stratify patients into risk classes. The score helps determine appropriate care settings and treatment intensity based on mortality risk assessment.

result.description: PSI/PORT score determining pneumonia severity and mortality risk class

ranges.interpretation: Low risk for mortality. Outpatient treatment recommended. 30-day mortality rate <1-3%. Consider outpatient oral antibiotics and close follow-up.
Low risk for mortality. Outpatient treatment vs. observation admission. 30-day mortality rate <3%. Consider brief hospitalization or intensive outpatient monitoring.
Moderate risk for mortality. Inpatient admission recommended. 30-day mortality rate 8-9%. Requires hospitalization with standard care and monitoring.
High risk for mortality. Inpatient admission with consideration for ICU care. 30-day mortality rate 27-31%. Requires aggressive treatment and close monitoring.

Aujesky D, Auble TE, Yealy DM, Stone RA, Obrosky DS, Meehan TP, et al. Prospective comparison of three validated prediction rules for prognosis in community-acquired pneumonia. Am J Med. 2005;118(4):384-92. doi: 10.1016/j.amjmed.2005.01.006.
formula: Sum of demographic points (age + sex adjustment) + comorbidity points + clinical findings points + laboratory findings points
notes: Most extensively validated pneumonia severity score with over 50,000 patients studied
Preferred over CURB-65 in 2019 ATS/IDSA guidelines for community-acquired pneumonia
Age contributes absolute value as points (e.g., 65-year-old gets 65 points for age)
Female sex provides -10 point adjustment due to lower mortality risk
Class I patients are young (<50 years) with no comorbidities or high-risk findings
May underestimate severity in young patients with severe pneumonia
Does not apply to patients with HIV, immunosuppression, or hospital-acquired pneumonia
Laboratory values (pH, PaO2) are optional but improve accuracy when available
Originally developed and validated in US and Canadian populations
Helps standardize admission decisions and reduce unnecessary hospitalizations
Should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment and patient preferences
Cost-effective tool for healthcare resource allocation and quality improvement
